fields.headline: Lies and legacies
fields.bodyText: "In 2002 their jointly written book failed to appeal to established publishers in the west," noted Robert Service in the Sunday Times, reviewing Alexander Litvinenko and Yuri Felshtinsky's Blowing Up Russia. "It has taken Litvinenko's murder for the book to appear in this updated edition ... as vivid a condemnation of the Putin regime as has yet been written." "Blowing Up Russia is devoted to one phenomenon - how the security service of a huge state became a criminal, mafia-type organisation targeted against the population of its own country," wrote Oleg Gordievsky in the Times. "With numerous examples the authors attempt to show how terrorist acts were carried out, money was laundered, people killed and shadowy businesses started up and closed down in the interests of Chekists who had managed to place their own man, Putin, at the top of the country's governing pyramid." "If Blowing Up Russia demands our attention," said Nicholas Shakespeare in the Daily Telegraph, "it is because of Litvinenko's claim to know where a lot of the bodies are buried, who shot them, who dug the graves and who issued the orders that have resulted in a 'democratic' government controlled 'absolutely' by the FSB." "Craig Nelson's excellent book strikes a balance between sympathy and criticism," wrote David Horspool in the Daily Telegraph of Thomas Paine: His Life, His Time and the Birth of Modern Nations. "Most convincingly, it brings out the force of Paine's writing." "With a panache worthy of Paine himself, Nelson reinstates his subject as a progressive thinker and passionate activist as relevant to our times as to his own," said Iain Finlayson in the Times. Paine died thinking he had failed, explained Cal McCrystal in the Independent on Sunday: "Nevertheless, today, nearly half of the world's nations have democratic elections and the freedoms which Paine's revolutionary generation hoped to achieve." "Trickster Travels: In Search of Leo Africanus, a 16th-century Muslim Between Worlds is a masterpiece of scholarship," declared Michael Binyon in the Times, "tracking down this elusive and ambiguous polymath who moved between two clashing worlds and was embraced by neither." "Natalie Zemon Davis has spent 40 years studying the man, his work and his world and she is better placed than almost anyone else to recreate him," observed Anthony Sattin in the Sunday Times. "But what starts as absorbing historical narrative turns into the sort of dry textual analysis that belongs in academic journals, not a book for general readers. By the end ... this reader had stopped caring." "'Whatever else, one must not be boring'," wrote Sam Alexandroni in the New Statesman. "Davis quotes this golden rule of Arab literature without paying enough attention to it herself."
